title: 108_s2205
content:
There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so I will summarize the curr_chunk directly.

Summarized chunk:
"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Congress finds that Ukraine allows its citizens the right to emigrate without excessive taxes or charges, has been compliant with freedom of emigration requirements since 1997, and has made progress towards democracy since 1991. Ukraine has taken important steps towards creating democratic institutions and a free-market economy, committed to developing governance in line with human rights principles. It has also shown progress in meeting international commitments and standards. Ukraine has made progress in meeting international commitments and standards in its recent Parliamentary elections, despite significant shortcomings in implementing election laws and allegations of interference and intimidation. As an OSCE participating state, Ukraine is committed to addressing issues related to national and religious minorities for their full equality. Ukraine has enacted legislation to protect against incitement to violence based on discrimination, including anti-Semitism. Efforts have been made to combat ethnic and religious intolerance through cooperation with US NGOs. Ukraine is also continuing the restitution of religious properties. Ukraine is progressing in the restitution of religious properties confiscated from minorities during the Soviet era and is developing a legislative framework for this process. Additionally, Ukraine has received normal trade relations treatment since a bilateral trade agreement with the United States in 1992 and is moving towards accession to certain agreements. Ukraine is making progress towards joining the World Trade Organization, addressing issues such as access for US agricultural products, intellectual property rights, tariff reductions, trade in services, agricultural subsidies, export incentives, and customs reform. Additionally, Ukraine has implemented protections for internationally recognized labor rights. Ukraine has committed to respecting freedom of the press and establishing positive relations with neighboring countries, while also expressing a desire for European integration and democracy. Ukraine has cooperated with the United States in peacekeeping operations in Europe and in the global fight against terrorism. Termination of application of Title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 to Ukraine. The President may determine that Title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 no longer applies to Ukraine and proclaim the extension of permanent normal trade relations treatment to Ukrainian products. The extension of nondiscriminatory treatment to Ukrainian products under Title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 will cease to apply. The extension of nondiscriminatory treatment to Ukrainian products under Title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 will cease to apply. Congress expresses its viewpoint. The Congress emphasizes the importance of the United States' continued engagement with Ukraine, urging Ukraine to fulfill its commitments under the OSCE, including promoting free emigration, safeguarding religious liberty, and combating discrimination and violence. The Congress urges Ukraine to fulfill commitments under the OSCE, including promoting free emigration, safeguarding religious liberty, combating discrimination and violence, expanding restitution of properties, respecting media freedoms, improving intellectual property rights enforcement, and ensuring quick resolution of issues. The United States is working with Ukraine to resolve trade disputes, particularly in the poultry and agricultural sectors. They are also monitoring human rights, rule of law, and media freedoms in Ukraine, providing assistance to NGOs and human rights groups, and attempting to establish annual discussions on these issues. The United States and Ukrainian NGOs are involved in discussions on trade disputes, human rights, rule of law, and media freedoms. The reporting requirement under the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 will continue to assess issues outlined in section 3(1), while rights under the June 23, 1992 bilateral trade agreement will be maintained. The Congress acknowledges the ongoing trade agreement between the United States and Ukraine, granting the US rights to utilize safeguard rules against import surges from Ukraine. Section 421 of the Trade Act of 1974 applies to Ukraine similar to China, as long as the trade agreement remains valid. Congressional oversight over WTO accession negotiations is emphasized. The President must notify Congress within 5 days of the US-Ukraine bilateral agreement on WTO accession. A report detailing the agreement must be transmitted to Congress within 15 days. If a resolution of disapproval is introduced in Congress within 30 days, it may impact the agreement. The 30-day period for Congress to consider a resolution of disapproval begins when the President notifies Congress of the agreement. A resolution of disapproval is a joint resolution of both Houses of Congress. The Congress is considering a resolution of disapproval regarding the agreement between the United States and Ukraine on Ukraine's accession to the World Trade Organization. The resolution states that the agreement does not adequately advance the interests of the United States. The resolution can be introduced by any Member of the House of Representatives. In the House, a resolution may be introduced by any Member, referred to the Committee on Ways and Means and Rules, and cannot be amended. In the Senate, a resolution may be introduced by any Member and referred for consideration. The resolution introduced in the House is referred to the Committee on Ways and Means and Rules and cannot be amended. The resolution introduced in the Senate is referred for consideration. The resolution of disapproval cannot be amended and follows specific procedures for committee discharge and floor consideration. The Congress enacts subsection (b) as part of the rules of the House of Representatives and the Senate, superseding other rules if inconsistent. Each House retains the right to change its rules regarding procedures at any time. The Congress enacts subsection (b) as part of the rules of the House of Representatives and the Senate, superseding other rules if inconsistent. Each House retains the right to change its rules regarding procedures at any time, in the same manner, and to the same extent as any other rule of that House.
